Kundig SOCIETE DES NATIONSdeuxieme assembleeRapports presentes par la Premiere Commission sur les propositions cTamendements au Pacte.le 30 septembre 1921.ARTICLE 1".La proposition faite par la DiUgation argentine a la pvemibre Assemblee,Rapporteur: M. Scialoja.M. H. Pueyrredon, au nom de la Delegation argentine, a propose le 4 decem-bre 1920, pour Particle ier du Pacte de la Societe des Nations, 1'amendement suivant:k Que tous les Etats souverains reconnus par la Communaute interna-tionale soient admis a faire partie de la Societe des Nations, de telle facon que leur non-incorporation soit le resultat d'une decision volontaire de leur part, nLa proposition etait fondee sur cette consideration: a La force de la Societe des Nations reside dans Incorporation du plus grand nombre d'Etats; moins elle en comptera en dehors de sa loi, plus nombreux seront les Membres soumis a sa discipline et a 1'accomplissement des devoirs que la Societe des Nations impose. La non-admission de quelques pays pourrait creer des antagonismes dangereux, etre 1'origine d'une Ligue d'Etats formee contre la Societe dont ils ne feraient point partie, et constituer une cause d'inquietude constante pour la paix du monde. bL'amendement propose n'a pas le caractere d'une simple amelioration partielle du texte actuel, mais il tend a transformer radicalement 1'essence meme de la Societe des Nations. La Commission, avec raison, a fait preceder 1'etude de la formule proposee qu'on ne peut, selon la declaration des auteurs eux-memes, considerer comme parfaite de 1'examen de 1'idee dont elle s'inspire.L'intention qui a pousse la Republique argentine a prendre 1'initiative d'une disposition tendant a ouvrir sans condition les portes de la Societe a tous les Etats, est sans doute tres elevee, et si les conditions politiques et morales actuelles du monde repondaient a 1'ideal vers lequel aspire chacun de nous, on arriverait peut-etre a surmonter, en corrigeant le texte, les difncultes d'ordre strictement juridique qui pourraient etre opposees a la formule nouvelle. Mais, malheureusement, la realite actuelle est encore trop eloignee de cet ideal et la Societe des Nations devra, long-temps encore, se considerer plutot comme un moyen efncace pour 1'humanite de se rapprocher de cet ideal que comme la realisation immediate de cet ideal meme.Parmi les Etats qui ne font pas encore partie de la Societe des Nations, il en est un des plus grands qui n'a point encore voulu 6tre incorpore, tandis que d'autres ne sont pas encore en mesure de satisfaire a ces conditions essentielles de stabilite, de liberte et de securite que 1'execution des devoirs inherents a la qualite de Membre de la Societe implique et exige. La recente experience de la Societe des Nations a prouve que quelques Etats ne sont pas encore, par suite de leur situation, en mesure cTetre incorpores, meme s'ils le demandent. La volonte positive et la capacite des membres sont necessaires pour qu'ils puissent faire partie d'une societe et pour qu'ils puissent s'engager a executer les droits et les devoirs de membre de la societe.La qualite meme d'Etat souverain reconnu par la communaute' internationale, sur laquelle est fonde, dans Pamendement argentin, le droit d'appartenir a la Societe des Nations, ne repond pas a une idee bien determinee. Tandis que, d'une part, une souverainete imparfaite pourrait paraitre suffisante, on ne peut, d'autre part, definir avec precision, en termes juridiques, en quoi consiste la reconnaissance de la communaute internationale. II existe des Etats qui sont reconnus de facto et ne le sont pas de jure; il en existe qui sont reconnus seulement par certains autres.Comment et quand pourra-t-on dire que la communaute internationale a accorde sa reconnaissance ? Et dans quelle condition juridique un Etat se trouve-rait-il entre le moment de son admission ipso jure, en vertu du nouvel article ier et celui de sa declaration negative eventuelle ou de son refus de.s'acquitter de ses obli-gations comme Membre de la Societe des Nations ? LEAGUE OF NATIONSSECOND ASSEMBLYReports presented by the First Committee regarding Amendments to the Covenant.September 30th, 1921.ARTICLE 1.The Proposal of the Argentine Delegation at the First Assembly.Rapporteur: M. Scialoja.M. H. Pueyrredon, on December 4th, 1920, proposed, in the name of the Argentine Delegation, the following amendment to Article 1 of the Covenant of the League of Nations: "That all sovereign States recognised by the Community of Nations be admitted to join the League of Nations in such a manner that if they do not become Members of the League, this can only be the result of a voluntary decision on their part."The proposal was based on the consideration that "the strength of the League of Nations depends on its including the greatest possible number of States; the fewer the States outside it, the greater will be the number of the Members pledged to carry out its provisions and to perform the duties which it imposes. The non-admission of a number of States might lead to dangerous antagonisms, be the cause of the formation of a League of States outside the League, in rivalry to it, and be a constant source of danger to the peace of the world."This amendment does not represent a mere partial improvement of the present text, but it rather aims at a radical transformation of the actual character of the League of Nations. The Committee, before entering upon the examination of the reading proposed which the authors themselves declare imperfect has very rightly turned its attention to the principle on which the amendment is based.The Argentine Republic was undoubtedly actuated by the highest motives in proposing a clause which would unconditionally throw open the doors of the League to all States; and if the actual moral and political conditions of the world were of a nature to support the ideal which everyone of us cherishes in his heart, the difficulties of a purely legal value which could be raised against the new reading of Article 1 might perhaps be removed. But actual circumstances are, unhappily, still too far removed from that ideal, and the League of Nations cannot for a long time yet hope to bring about its immediate realisation, but must rather be content to act as an efficient instrument in the progress of humanity towards the goal.One of the largest of the States which are not yet Members of the League is for the present not willing to take part in it, whilst others are not able yet to fulfil the essential conditions of stability, freedom and security in the fulfilment of the obligations which are incumbent upon every Member of the League. The recent experience of the League has proved that the conditions of some States render them unfit for admission, even should they request it. The admission of Members to a Society, and their assumption of the rights and duties thereby incurred, are necessarily based upon the will and capacity of these Members.The actual qualify of Sovereign States recognised by the Community of Nations, upon which, according to the Argentine amendment, the rights of admission to the League of Nations are founded, does not express a well-defined idea. While, on the one hand, an imperfect sovereignty might appear sufficient, on the other hand, recognition by the Community of Nations cannot be expressed in precise legal terms. Some States are recognised de facto and not de jure; some are recog-nised only by certain other States.When and how can it be said that the Community of Nations has conferred its recognition ? What would be the legal condition of a State between the moment s of its admission ipso jure on the basis of the new Article 1, and the moment of its possible negative declaration or its refusal to fulfil the obligations of membership ? La modification, en outre, dans la forme proposed est tellement radicale, telle-ment en opposition avec les principes fondamentaux inscrits, a 1'article ier du Pacte et auxquels la grande majorite de la Commission a declare vouloir rester fidele, qu'il en deviendrait necessaire de modifier plusieurs autres dispositions du Pacte, elles aussi de la plus haute importance, comme celles des articles 8, 9, 16 et 17.En consequence, la Commission a le regret de declarer que, malgre la possibility de remedier par des modifications de texte a plusieurs des inconvenients de la propo-sition argentine, il y a lieu, a, son avis, en attendant que puisse etre accepte le prin-cipe qui y est contenu, et vu la regrettable absence de la Delegation de la Repu-blique argentine, d'ajourner toute decision sur sa proposition d'amendement.Le 21 septembre 1921.ARTICLE i".La situation des petits Etats.Rapporteur: M. Herluf Zahle.Les premier et deuxieme alineas de 1'article 1 du Pacte, ainsi queTannexeau Pacte, font bien une distinction entre les Membres originaires de la SocieHe et les Etats qui ont adhere plus tard, mais, une fois l'admission faite, cette difference devient sans importance pratique. II n'y a done qu'une seule categorie de Membres de la Societe.II est vrai que la cinquieme Commission de la premiere Assemblee, dans ses rap-ports sur. la demande d'admission de plusieurs Etats, parexemple: 1'Esthonie, la Lettonie, etc., a recommande a 1'Assemblee de leur permettre de participer aux orga-nisationstechniques de la Societe qui sont d'interet general; cette Commission a, en meme temps, propose a 1'Assemblee de recommander a la Conference internationale du Travail, d'examiner s'il ne serait pas possible d'admettre eventuellement ces Etats dans 1'Organisation internationale du Travail, mais cette adhesion eventuelle aux organes speciaux de la Societe des Nations n'implique nullement pour ces Etats la qualite de Membre de la Societe.Cependant, dans sa seance du 17 decembre 1920, 1'Assemblee a adopte le vceu suivant :c L'Assemblee exprime le voeu que la Commission speciale qui sera chargee parleConseilde la Societe des Nations d'examiner les propositions relatives aux modifications du Pacte, veuille bien examiner si, et comment, il serait possible derattacher a la Societe des Nations des Etats souverains qui, eh raison de leur exiguiite, ne peuvent etre admis comme Membres ordinaires. sI. Avant la premiere Assemblee de la Societe des Nations, plusieurs Etats de faible etendue avaient demande leur admission a la Societe des Nations.1. Le 25 avril 1919, le charge d'affaires de la Republique de Saint-Marin a adresse au President de la Conference de la Paix une demande a cet effet;2. Le 6 avril 1920, le Secretaire d'Etat de la Principaute de Monaco a adresse au President du Conseil de la Societe des Nations une demande visant le m6me but; et3. Lei5 juillet 1920, le Ministre de la Suisse a Londres, la Suisse ayant assume la representation diplomatique de la Principaute de Liechtenstein aupres du Gou-vernement de Sa Majeste Britannique, a demande 1'admission de cette Principaute a la Societe des Nations.La question del'admission de la Republique de Saint-Marin et de la Princi-paute de Monaco n'a pas ete discutee par la cinquieme Commission de la premiere Assemblee de la Societe des Nations, et pour des raisons differentes.Ad. 1. En ce qui concerne la question de 1'admission de la Republique de Saint-Marin, le Secretaire general, en date du 24 aout 1920, a demande certains rensei-gnements au Gouvernement de la Republique de Saint-Marin; mais aucune reponse a la question posee n'est parvenue au Secretariat general, pendant la session de la premiere Assemblee qui, par consequent, n'a pas eu a s'occuper de la question de 1'admission de cette Republique.Ad. 2. En ce qui concerne la Principaute de Monaco, la demande d'admission a ete retiree par lettre du 22 octobre 1920.Par consequent, la cinquieme Commission de la premiere Assemblee n'a r^dige aucun rapport sur 1'admission de ces deux Etats. Moreover, the modification, in the form in which it is proposed, is so radical and so contrary to the fundamental principles contained in Article i of the Covenant, by which the great majority of the Committee have expressed their desire to abide, that it would create the necessity of modifying several other provisions of the Cove-nant which are.also of the greatest importance, as, for instance, those of Articles 8, 9, 16 and 17.Accordingly, though several of the difficulties involved in the Argentine pro-posal might be remedied by textual changes, the Committee reluctantly states its opinion that, in view of the regrettable absence of the Delegation of the Argen-tine Republic, and until the principle contained in its proposal can be accepted, any decision on the amendment moved by the Argentine Republic should be post-poned.September 21st, 1921.ARTICLE 1. It was of the opinion that it was very desirable for the development of the League of Nations that the latter should, as soon as possible, include all those States which have fulfilled the conditions laid down in Article 1 of the Covenant, and which wish to join the League. This principle applies equally, although with less importance, to States of a very small area, since every State constitutes a moral entity whose susceptibilities should be respected. Moreover, the true object of the League, the development of co-operation among nations, with a view to guaranteeing peace and security, would be more readily attained if a certain class of States, even States of secondary importance, were not excluded.2, The main difficulty was the form which their attachment to the League should take. This period would give the Assembly an opportunity to demonstrate in the Session following that at which the amendments were voted its desire that Members of the League should hasten the ratification, and, moreover, when resolutions for amendments were nullified on account of an in-sufficiency of ratifications, the promoters of such amendments would be able to present them again in a modified form at the next meeting of the Assembly, two years after the first vote.The Committee proposes to mention this period in the text of the amendment " to Article 26.The Committee discussed the right conferred upon any Member of the League, by the second paragraph of Article 26, not to accept amendments to the Covenant, in which case it ceases to be a Member of the League.It was recognised that the second paragraph of Article 26 could not be con-sidered as limiting the effects of the coming into force of amendments which shall have received the requisite ratifications. The binding force of these amendments extends to all Members. The only right reserved for those whose opposition to the amendment is unshakable is to mark their refusal to accept it, by which refusal they cease ipso facto to be Members of the League.It appears in conformity with the spirit of this provision that such a decision should be notified to all the Members of the League through the Secretary-General.When should such a communication be made? Obviously, after the com ng into force of an amendment; but the Committee considered that it was not prudent to leave the Members of the League which had not ratified free for an indefinite period to secede from the League without giving notice of their intention and observing the other conditions laid down in Article 1 of the Covenant. The Committee pro-poses that the right conferred upon Members of the League by paragraph 2 of Article 26 shall only be exercisable within the year following the notification of the coming into force of an amendment.The text of the amendment to Article 26 proposed by the Committee alludes to this time limit.
